message_1: What is the standard enthalpy of formation of ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3) given that the standard enthalpies of formation of NH3 and HNO3 are -46.1 kJ/mol and -206.6 kJ/mol, respectively?
message_2:
To find the standard enthalpy of formation of ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3), we can use the following equation:

ΔHf(NH4NO3) = ΔHf(NH3) + ΔHf(HNO3) - ΔHf(N2) - ΔHf(H2O)

However, since the formation of elements in their standard states (N2 and H2O in this case) have an enthalpy of formation equal to zero, the equation simplifies to:

ΔHf(NH4NO3) = ΔHf(NH3) + ΔHf(HNO3)

Now, we can plug in the given values for the enthalpies of formation of NH3 and HNO3:

ΔHf(NH4NO3) = (-46.1 kJ/mol) + (-206.6 kJ/mol)

ΔHf(NH4NO3) = -252.7 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy of formation of ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3) is -252.7 kJ/mol.
